awd_titl_txt: NSF/MCB-BSF: Systematic analysis of degrons recognized for nuclear protein quality control
awd_abstract_narration:
Cell physiology and viability depend on proteins adopting precise 3-dimensional (3D) structures that provide the correct architecture for protein function and activity. Proteins can often become damaged and lose their correct 3D structures thus making them more prone to aggregation and the formation of toxic aggregates.  Misfolded protein aggregation is a fundamental problem that all cells encounter, either randomly due to errors in protein synthesis or as a stress-induced phenomenon caused by exposure of proteins to damaging agents. To counteract misfolded protein aggregation, eukaryotic cells have evolved robust organelle-specific protein quality control (PQC) pathways that manage these proteins. This project seeks to examine the mechanisms of targeting of misfolded and aggregated proteins to different PQC pathways in the model organism, Saccharomyces cerevisiae (budding yeast), using high throughput screening and computational analysis.  It will also reveal the key features of misfolded protein toxicity in the nucleus.  More broadly, the research will provide numerous training opportunities for scientists at all levels of experience, from high school and undergraduate students to graduate students and research scientists. Publically available datasets will be created from the data generated. International workshops will also be created to provide a global means for education and information dissemination. 

The focus of this research is to understand how the nuclear organelle in eukaryotic cells protects itself from proteins that have become incorrectly folded and form toxic aggregates by examining the mechanisms of targeting misfolded proteins through the multiple ubiquitin-proteasome system protein quality control (UPS PQC) pathways. The experimental system is designed to maximize the probability of identifying the spectrum of degradation signals that govern the UPS PQC degradation pathways in the nucleus. To this end, a library of yeast cDNA fragments will be constructed and appended to a nuclear reporter system. The resulting nuclear protein library will enable measurement of the contribution of each individual fragment to protein stability. Specifically, to sort the different UPS PQC pathways in the nucleus, the reporter library will be expressed in yeast strains with single or combined deletions of specific nuclear PQC ubiquitin ligases. Data analysis will rely on in-depth bioinformatics that will correlate the destabilizing elements with their affecting pathway(s). Subsequently, the destabilizing sequences (degrons) will be compared to sequences identified by a complementary yeast 2-hybrid analysis as interaction sequences of nuclear proteins with their cognate ubiquitin ligases. Once degrons are classified by their cognate degradation pathways, further computational analyses will discern structural features particularly degron sequence, structure, biochemical and biophysical properties. Distinct features will be tested experimentally. To better understand the relationship between a tendency of a degron to aggregate and its contribution to cell toxicity, a combination of cell-growth and fluorescent assays will be employed. Altogether, the identification of novel UPS PQC degrons will enable systematic investigation of misfolded protein quality control in the nucleus. This, in turn, will provide new biological hypotheses about how misfolded proteins aggregates and its consequences.
 
This collaborative US/Israel project is supported by the US National Science Foundation and the Israeli Binational Science Foundation.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Cell function and viability depend on the maintenance of proper protein folding. The failure to eliminate proteins that misfold often leads to the formation of toxic aggregates as seen in diseases like Alzheimer's. To avoid toxic aggregation, cells use protein quality control (PQC) systems to manage misfolded proteins. One of the most prominent PQC systems involves destruction of misfolded proteins by the ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS). Historically, PQC degradation studies have focused primarily on the endoplasmic reticulum and the cytoplasm, and the field has a decent grasp of how PQC systems in these compartments operate. Fewer studies have focused on PQC in the nucleus and the general understanding of how PQC systems operate in the nucleus remains rudimentary. The long-term goals of this project were to understand how the nucleus normally protects itself from toxic misfolded proteins by identifying and characterizing the misfolded protein features (or degrons) that nuclear PQC degradation pathways recognize, and examining how toxicity develops if these degrons are not appropriately targeted. Because protein misfolding is a basic issue that all eukaryotes face, we have been using the single-cell eukaryote Saccharomyces cerevisiae as a model system to understand nuclear PQC degradation. From studies in our labs and in other labs, we have learned that the ubiquitin ligases San1, Doa10, and Ubr1 operate in nuclear PQC degradation. Several salient questions remained unanswered. Why are distinct ubiquitin ligases required for nuclear PQC degradation? What are their specific targets? How do they cooperate to prevent misfolded nuclear protein cytotoxicity?

Intellectual Merit:A major constraint for comprehensive studies of misfolded protein degradation by the cellular PQC systems is a lack of large datasets for PQC degrons and their associated pathways. This greatly limits our ability to appreciate PQC degradation as a network, since we currently do not have enough basic information to allow intensive comparison of the different pathways and the degrons they target. Consequently, drawing broad conclusions about PQC degradation and the features of misfolding recognized in their substrates is still very challenging. Here we employed unbiased screens in yeast to identify large sets of consensus degrons for each nuclear PQC pathway. We used meta-analyses to reveal the specific characteristics of the degrons that drive them towards one specific pathway versus another. Lastly, we identified proteins involved in the formation of misfolded nuclear protein aggregates, and revealed the underlying key features of misfolded protein toxicity in the nucleus.

Broader Impacts: The approaches put forth in this proposal provided numerous training opportunities for scientists at all levels of experience, from starting level researchers like high school and undergraduate students to graduate students and research scientists. Graduate students had the opportunity to present their research at national and international meetings. The Gardner lab continued outreach efforts by increasing recruitment and retention of underrepresented groups in science during the award. The lab continuied participation in the UW School of Medicine Office of Multicultural Affairs U-DOC high school summer program that focuses on high school students from Washington State who come from a disadvantaged background (economic, geographic, education) and/or students who are underrepresented in medicine in science. During the award, the PI also attended the national ABRCMS (Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students) and SACNAS meetings (Society for Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science) meetings to help recruit underrepresented minority students into both the UW Pharmacology and Molecular & Cellular Biology graduate programs.


Last Modified: 11/18/2021
Modified by: Richard G Gardner
